  "article_text": [
    "it is well - known that the usual continued fraction algorithm is encoded by the dynamics of the gauss map @xmath4 ; moreover , the gauss map is known to be related , via a poincar section , to the geodesic flow on the modular surface @xmath5 . in greater generality ,",
    "the modular group @xmath1 is generated by the transformations @xmath6 and @xmath7 , and several different continued fraction algorithms have been constructed by applying the generators according to different rules .    in particular",
    ", for each @xmath8 we can construct an interval map @xmath0 by fixing a `` fundamental interval '' @xmath9 , and at each step applying the inversion @xmath10 followed by as many translations @xmath11 as are needed to come back to the fundamental domain .",
    "thus , for each @xmath12 , we have the interval map @xmath13 \\to [ \\alpha -1 , \\alpha]$ ] defined by @xmath14 and @xmath15 where @xmath16 is chosen so that the result lies in @xmath9 .",
    "each @xmath0 determines a continued fraction expansion of type @xmath17 with coefficients @xmath18 . similarly to the gauss map , each @xmath0 has infinitely many expanding branches and a unique absolutely continuous invariant measure @xmath19 .    in recent years",
    ", s. katok and i. ugarcovici , following a suggestion of d. zagier , defined the two - dimensional family @xmath20 of _ @xmath2-continued fraction transformations _ and studied their dynamics and natural extensions @xcite .",
    "the maps @xmath0 are the first return maps of @xmath21 on the interval @xmath9 and , as it will be explained , they capture all the essential dynamical features . the family @xmath0 interpolates between other well - known continued fraction algorithms : in particular , for @xmath22 one gets the _ continued fraction to the nearest integer _ going back to hurwitz @xcite , while for @xmath23 one gets the _ backward continued fraction _ which is related to the reduction theory of quadratic forms @xcite .",
    "the definition of @xmath0 is very similar to the definition of the _ @xmath8-continued fraction transformations _",
    "@xmath24 introduced by nakada @xcite and subsequently studied by several authors @xcite . in this paper",
    "we shall use techniques similar to the ones in @xcite to study the @xmath0 : as we shall see in greater detail , this will also highlight the substantial differences in the combinatoral structures of the respective bifurcation sets . in particular , we shall see that the bifurcation set is canonically isomorphic to the set of external rays landing on the main cardioid of the mandelbrot set ( while the bifurcation set for the @xmath8-continued fractions was shown to be isomorphic to the real slice of the mandelbrot set @xcite ) .    from a dynamical systems perspective , we shall be interested in studying the variation of the dynamics of @xmath0 as a function of the parameter .",
    "as we shall see , there exist infinitely many islands of `` stability '' , and each of them corresponds to a _",
    "farey word _",
    "( see section [ s : farey ] ) .",
    "namely , to each farey word @xmath25 we shall associate an open interval @xmath26 $ ] called _ quadratic maximal interval _ , or _ qumterval _ for short ( see section [ s : qumtervals ] ) ; the _ bifurcation set _",
    "@xmath3 is defined as the complement of all such intervals : @xmath27 \\setminus \\bigcup_{w \\in fw } j_w.\\ ] ] the set @xmath3 is homeomorphic to a cantor set and has hausdorff dimension zero ( proposition [ hdim ] ) . we shall prove that on each @xmath28 we have the following matching between the orbits of @xmath8 and @xmath29 ; namely , there exist integers @xmath30 and @xmath31 ( which depend only on @xmath28 ) such that @xmath32 for all @xmath33 .",
    "one way to study the bifurcations of the family @xmath0 is by considering its entropy , in the spirit of @xcite .",
    "indeed , let us define @xmath34 to be the metric entropy of the map @xmath0 with respect to the measure @xmath19 .",
    "we shall prove that the set @xmath3 is precisely the set of parameters for which the entropy function is not smooth :    [ t : more ] the function @xmath35    1 .",
    "is analytic on @xmath36\\setminus { \\mathcal{e}_{ku}}$ ] ; 2 .",
    "is not differentiable ( and not locally lipschitz ) at any @xmath37 .",
    "thus , as the parameter @xmath8 varies , the dynamics of @xmath0 goes through infinitely many stable regimes , one for each connected component of the complement of @xmath3 .",
    "we shall prove , however , that the entropy function is globally monotone across the bifurcations . in order to state the theorem ,",
    "let us note that the graph of the entropy function is symmetric with respect to the transformation @xmath38 , because @xmath0 and @xmath39 are measurably conjugate ( see equation ) .",
    "moreover , it is not hard by an explicit computation to see that the entropy is constant ( equal to @xmath40 ) on the interval @xmath41 $ ] , where @xmath42 is the golden mean ( so @xmath43 ) .",
    "the main theorem is the following monotonicity result for @xmath44 :    [ t : main ] the function @xmath35 is strictly monotone increasing on @xmath45 $ ] , constant on @xmath46 $ ] and strictly monotone decreasing on @xmath47 $ ] .",
    "note that theorem [ t : main ] highlights a major difference with the @xmath8-continued fraction case , where the entropy is not monotone @xcite in any neighbourhood of @xmath48 , and actually the set of parameters where the entropy is locally non - monotone has hausdorff dimension @xmath49 @xcite . for the @xmath0 ,",
    "the study of the metric entropy was introduced by katok and ugarcovici in @xcite , @xcite , who gave an algorithm to produce the natural extension for any given element in the complement of @xmath3 ; as a consequence , they computed the entropy in some particular cases .",
    "the present work gives a global approach which makes it possible to study the entropy as a function of the parameter .",
    "condition was introduced in @xcite , where it is called _ cycle property _ , and it is also completely analogous to the _ matching condition _ used by nakada and natsui @xcite to study the family @xmath50 .    finally , we shall prove ( proposition [ p : limit ] ) that the entropy tends to @xmath51 as @xmath52 , and there its modulus of continuity is of order @xmath53 ( which is the same behaviour as in the case of @xmath8-continued fractions ) .",
    "as a function of @xmath8 , and a sequence of zooms around a parameter in the bifurcation set @xmath3 .",
    "note the slope is increasing in each zoom , due to the fact that the entropy is not locally lipschitz at points of @xmath3 ( theorem [ t : more ] ) .",
    "however , the entropy is globally monotone on @xmath54 $ ] , as stated in theorem [ t : main ] . ]",
    "the fact that each connected component of the complement of @xmath3 is naturally labelled by a farey word can be used to draw an unexpected connection between the combinatorial structure of @xmath3 and the mandelbrot set .    recall the _",
    "main cardioid _ of the mandelbrot set is the set of parameters @xmath55 for which the map @xmath56 has an attractive or indifferent fixed point .",
    "the exterior of the mandelbrot set admits a canonical uniformization map , and to each angle @xmath57 there corresponds an associated _ external ray _",
    "let us denote @xmath59 to be the set of angles @xmath60 for which the ray @xmath58 lands on the main cardioid .",
    "recall minkowski s _ question mark function _",
    "\\to [ 0 , 1]$ ] is a homeomorphism of the interval which is defined by converting the continued fraction expansion of a number into a binary expansion .",
    "more precisely , if @xmath62 $ ] is the usual continued fraction expansion of @xmath63 , then we define @xmath64 we shall prove that minkowski s function induces the following correspondence .",
    "[ t : mandel ] minkowski s question mark function @xmath65 maps homeomorphically the bifurcation set @xmath3 onto the set @xmath59 of external angles of rays landing on the main cardioid of the mandelbrot set . in formulas , we have @xmath66    the connection may seem incidental , but it is an instance of a more general correspondence discovered by the authors in recent years . indeed , the minkowski map provides an explicit dictionary between sets of numbers defined using continued fractions and sets of external angles for certain fractals arising in complex dynamics .",
    "more precisely , the question mark function :    1 .",
    "maps homeomorphically the _ bifurcation set for @xmath8-continued fractions _ onto the set of external rays landing on the _ real slice _ of the boundary of the mandelbrot set ( see @xcite and @xcite , theorem 1.1 ) ; 2 .   maps",
    "the sets of _ numbers of generalized bounded type _ defined in @xcite to the sets of external rays landing on the real slice of the boundary of julia sets for real quadratic polynomials ( @xcite , theorem 1.4 ) ; 3 .   conjugates the tuning operators defined by douady and hubbard for the real quadratic family to tuning operators corresponding to renormalization schemes for the @xmath8-continued fractions @xcite .    for an introduction and more details about such correspondence we refer to one of the authors thesis @xcite .",
    "the dictionary proves to be especially useful to derive results about families of continued fractions using the large body of information known about the combinatorics of the quadratic family ; moreover , it can also be used to obtain new results about the quadratic family and the mandelbrot set from the combinatorics of continued fractions ( e.g. @xcite , theorem 1.6 ) .",
    "being intimately connected to the structure of @xmath67 , farey words play a distinguished role in several other dynamical , combinatorial or algebraic problems . to list just a few ,",
    "we mention : kneading sequences for lorentz maps @xcite , the coding of cutting sequences on the flat torus @xcite as well as on the hyperbolic one - punctured torus ( @xcite , pg .",
    "726 - 727 ) ; the markov spectrum ( in particular the cohn tree , see @xcite , pg .",
    "201 ) ; primitive elements in rank two free groups @xcite ; the burrows - wheeler transform @xcite ; digital convexity @xcite . for more information",
    "we also refer to the survey @xcite or the books @xcite and @xcite .",
    "we conclude the introduction by explaining in more detail the results of @xcite and how they relate to the present paper . for further details ,",
    "see also section [ s : natext ] .    in @xcite ,",
    "katok and ugarcovici consider the two parameter family of continued fraction algorithms induced by the maps @xmath69 where the parameters @xmath68 range in a closed subset @xmath70 of the plane .",
    "the segment @xmath71\\}\\ ] ] is a piece of the boundary of @xmath70 , and the first return map of @xmath72 on the interval @xmath73 coincides with the map @xmath74 we are going to study ( these maps are also mentioned in @xcite under the name `` gauss - like maps '' and denoted @xmath75 ) .",
    "katok and ugarcovici also consider a closely related family @xmath76 of maps of the plane : each @xmath77 has an attractor @xmath78 such that @xmath77 restricted to @xmath79 is invertible and it is a geometric realization of the natural extension of @xmath20 . they also show that for most parameters in @xmath70 the attractor @xmath79 has _",
    "finite rectangular structure _ , meaning that it is a finite union of rectangles .",
    "moreover , all exceptions to this property belong to a cantor set @xmath80 which is contained in the critical line @xmath81 and whose 1-dimensional lebesgue measure is zero .",
    "it turns out that the set @xmath3 we are considering is just the projection of the set @xmath80 onto the second coordinate , up to a countable set .",
    "making explicit the structure of @xmath3 allows us to prove that it is not just a zero measure set , but it also has zero hausdorff dimension .",
    "in section [ s : farey ] we shall start defining farey words and establishing the properties which are needed to describe the combinatorial dynamics of the @xmath68-continued fractions .",
    "moreover , we define the _ binary bifurcation set _ @xmath82 and show how it is related to the main cardioid of the mandelbrot set .    in section [ s : rcf ]",
    "we then recall basic facts about continued fractions and then define the _ runlength map _",
    "@xmath83 which passes from binary expansions to continued fraction expansions ; then we shall see how the properties of farey words translate into the properties of the _ qumtervals _ which we shall define .",
    "then , we shall apply all these properties to the case of @xmath2-continued fractions ; in section [ s : matching ] we determine the combinatorial dynamics of the orbits of @xmath8 and @xmath29 , thus proving that the matching condition holds on each qumterval .    then , in section [ s : entropy ] we shall draw consequences for the entropy function , proving theorem [ t : main ] : indeed , we prove that the cantor set @xmath3 has hausdorff dimension zero ( proposition [ hdim ] ) and @xmath44 is hlder continuous , so it can be extended to a monotone function across the cantor set .",
    "finally , in section [ s : natext ] we shall combine the previous properties with the construction of the attractors given in @xcite to prove theorem [ t : more ] .",
    "for the sake of readability , the proofs of some technical lemmas will be postponed to the appendix .",
    "we wish to thank h. bruin , p. majer , c.g .",
    "moreira and i. ugarcovici for useful conversations .",
    "the pictures of the mandelbrot and julia sets are drawn with the software mandel of w. jung .",
    "we shall start by constructing the set of farey words and establishing the properties which are needed in the rest of the paper .",
    "many of these results appear in various sources , for instance in the books @xcite . for the convenience of the reader , and in order to set up the notation for the rest of the paper , we shall give a fairly self - contained treatment .",
    "an _ alphabet _ @xmath84 will be a finite set of symbols , which we shall call _ digits_. given an alphabet @xmath84 , we shall denote as @xmath85 the set of words of length @xmath86 , as @xmath87 the set of infinite words , and as @xmath88 the set of _ finite words _ of arbitrary length .",
    "if @xmath25 is a finite word , then the symbol @xmath89 will denote the infinite word given by infinite repetition of the word @xmath25 .",
    "if @xmath90 , we shall denote as @xmath91 the _ length _ of the word @xmath25 , i.e. the number of digits ; moreover , if we fix a digit @xmath92 , the symbol @xmath93 will denote the number of digits in the word which are equal to @xmath94 .",
    "moreover , given a word @xmath95 , we define its _ transpose _ to be the word @xmath96 with @xmath97 a word which is equal to its transpose is called _",
    "palindrome_. moreover , we define the _ cyclic permutation _ operator @xmath98 to act on the word @xmath99 as @xmath100    a total order @xmath101 on the alphabet @xmath84 induces , for each @xmath86 , a total order on the set @xmath85 of words of length @xmath86 by using the lexicographic order , and similarly it induces a total order on the set @xmath87 of infinite words .",

    "in the following we will mainly be interested in the binary alphabet @xmath117 , with the natural order @xmath118 .",

    "that every rational number can be obtained from @xmath51 and @xmath49 by taking successive farey sums of farey pairs , then @xmath195 is a farey word for any rational numbers @xmath223 $ ] , and the claim is proven .",
    "note moreover that the above @xmath163 is a bijection between the tree of farey words and the tree of farey fractions ; on one side , the operation is the concatenation of strings , while on the other side it is the farey sum .",

    "recall that a word @xmath302 which is minimal ( with respect to lexicographic order ) among all its cyclic permutations is also called a _ lyndon word _ , hence property ( e ) of lemma [ cyclic ] can be paraphrased as saying that every farey word is a lyndon word ( but not viceversa : e.g. , @xmath303 is a lyndon word but not a farey word ) .",
    "let us recall that all lyndon words of length greater than 1 begin with the digit @xmath51 and end with the digit @xmath49 ; moreover one has the following ( see @xcite )    [ p : lyndon ] if @xmath304 is a lyndon word ( in particular , if @xmath25 is a farey word ) , then @xmath305 .",
    "another way to generate farey words is by substitutions . given a pair of words @xmath306 } \\in \\{0,1\\}^ * \\times \\{0,1\\}^*$ ] we can define the _ substitution operator _ associated to @xmath307 to be the operator acting on @xmath125 ( or on @xmath308 ) as @xmath309 the action of @xmath307 on @xmath25 will be denoted by @xmath310 .",
    "let us note that if @xmath311 then the operator is order preserving while if @xmath312 it is order reversing ; moreover , the negation operator can be obtained as the substitution associated to @xmath313}$ ] .",

    "let us now highlight a connection between the combinatorics of farey words and the symbolic coding of rays landing on the main cardioid of the mandelbrot set .",
    "we shall start by recalling few standard facts in complex dynamics : for an account , we refer to @xcite and references therein .",
    "let us consider the family of quadratic polynomials @xmath364 with @xmath365 . recall the _ filled julia set _",

    "julia set _",

    "s theorem , if the julia set is locally connected , then all rays land .",

    "now , the set @xmath412 is the union of @xmath177 ( connected ) arcs , and the doubling map permutes their endpoints : hence , @xmath292 maps each arc of length smaller than @xmath340 homeomorphically to its image , and there is a unique arc @xmath413 of length at least @xmath340 . since the map @xmath375 is a local homeomorphism away from its critical point , then the component in the dynamical plane corresponding to @xmath413 must contain the critical point .",
    "now note that by lemma [ cyclic ] ( 1 ) and ( 3 ) , the arc @xmath414 is a connected component of @xmath412 , and by proposition [ l : book ] and the definition of @xmath82 , the length of @xmath415 is more than @xmath340 , so it must be @xmath416 the one which contains the critical point . as a consequence , the arc which contains the critical value is delimited by taking the forward image of the endpoints of @xmath413 ; thus , it is the arc @xmath417 and claim ( 2 ) is proven .",
    "as for the last statement , the previous construction implies the correspondence @xmath418 ; claim ( 3 ) follows by taking closures , as it is known that the set of angles of rays landing on the main cardioid is the closure of the set of rational angles of rays landing on the main cardioid ( see @xcite , corollary 4.4 ) .",

    "since both sets in are related to sets of rays landing in the mandelbrot set , it is intersting to see what our dictionary tells us when we transport the previous inclusion to the world of complex dynamics .",
    "first , using theorem [ t : mandel ] , the minkowski question mark @xmath590 maps @xmath3 homeomorphically to the set @xmath59 of external angles of rays landing on the main cardioid .",
    "meanwhile , by the main theorem of @xcite , the set @xmath588 is related to the set of rays landing on the real slice of the mandelbrot set . indeed ,",
    "if we let @xmath591 be the set of external angles of rays whose impression intersects the real slice of the mandelbrot set , then we have the homeomorphism ( @xcite , theorem 1.1 ) @xmath592 where @xmath593 .",
    "thus we have the following commutative diagram , where @xmath297 is the inclusion map : @xmath594 \\ar^{q}[d ]   \\ar[r]^{\\quad i } &    { \\mathcal{e}}_n \\ar^{\\psi}[d]\\\\ \\omega\\cap[0 , 1/2 ] \\ar@{.>}[r]^{\\quad t } & \\mathcal{r } } \\ ] ] as a consequence , the map @xmath595 , which can be just expressed as @xmath596 maps the set of rays landing on the upper half of the main cardioid into the set of real rays , i.e. @xmath597 for each @xmath598 $ ] .",
    "this fact is known in the folklore as `` douady s magic formula '' ( see @xcite , theorem 1.1 ) .",
    "let us return to the maps @xmath13 \\to [ \\alpha    -1 , \\alpha]$ ] which are defined by @xmath14 and @xmath600 the goal of this section is to prove that a matching condition between the orbits of the endpoints @xmath8 and @xmath29 is achieved for any parameter which belongs to some qumterval ( theorem [ t : anatomy ] and corollary [ c : weakmatching ] ) . in order to formulate the result precisely , we need some notation .",
    "recall the group @xmath601 acts on the real projective line by mbius transformations .",
    "indeed , if @xmath602 and @xmath603 then we shall write @xmath604 . the group @xmath601 is generated by the two elements @xmath605 and @xmath606 , which are represented by the matrices @xmath607 and act respectively as the inversion @xmath608 and the translation @xmath609 . for any fixed @xmath610 , the map @xmath0 is just given by the inversion followed by an integer power of the translation which brings the point back to the interval @xmath611 $ ] .",
    "thus , each branch of @xmath612 is represented by the map @xmath613 .",
    "now , in order to keep track of the inverse branches of the powers of @xmath0 , we shall now use the notation @xmath614 for each positive integer @xmath615 , and define the matrices @xmath616 note that these matrices represent the inverses of @xmath0 , in the sense that @xmath617 for each @xmath618 , x \\in [ \\alpha-1 , \\alpha ] , \\ell \\in \\mathbb{n}$ ] .",
    "finally , note that the family @xmath0 possesses the following fundamental symmetry : the maps @xmath0 and @xmath39 are measurably conjugate , namely one has @xmath619 for all @xmath620 \\setminus \\bigcup_{k \\in \\mathbb{z } } \\frac{1}{k-\\alpha}$ ] ( the countable set of exceptions is due to the convention about the floor function ) . as a consequence ,",
    "it is sufficient to study the dynamics for @xmath621 $ ] .",
    "we are now ready to formulate the main result of this section .",
    "[ t : anatomy ] let @xmath484 a farey word , @xmath622 and @xmath28 the corresponding qumterval ; let moreover @xmath485 denote the runlength of @xmath410 and @xmath623 $ ] be the pseudocenter of @xmath28 . then there exist two elements @xmath624 such that , for all @xmath33 we have the equalities @xmath625 moreover , the following _ matching condition _ holds : @xmath626    the matching condition implies the following identification between of the orbits of the two endpoints @xmath8 and @xmath29 .",
    "[ c : weakmatching ] for each parameter @xmath33 we have the identity @xmath627    note that implies that the first @xmath30 steps of the ( symbolic ) itinerary of @xmath8 is constant for all @xmath8 in the same qumterval , and the same is true for the first @xmath31 steps of the orbit of @xmath31 .",
    "a condition of this kind is called * strong cycle condition * in @xcite ; see section [ s : natext ] for a more detailed comparison .    as an illustration of theorem [ t : anatomy ] , let us consider the case @xmath33 with @xmath628 : it turns out that for every @xmath629 the following identity holds : @xmath630 indeed , this is due to the fact that the analytic expression of @xmath0 at the endpoints does not change as @xmath631 ; in this simple case in fact we can work out the explicit form of @xmath0 , and we get @xmath632 whence we have @xmath633 and @xmath634 , and we can check that @xmath635 which is an instance of equation .",
    "note that the essential point is that the matrices @xmath636 and @xmath637 do not depend on the particular @xmath8 as long as @xmath8 belongs to @xmath28 ; thus , the matching condition is just an identity between elements of the group @xmath601 .",
    "however , to different matching intervals @xmath28 there correspond different identities in the group .",
    "the proof of theorem [ t : anatomy ] follows from an explicit description of the symbolic orbits of @xmath8 and @xmath29 in terms of the regular continued fraction expansion of the pseudocenter of @xmath28 , as stated in the following proposition .",
    "[ r : mconcatenazione ] let @xmath500 ( hence @xmath638 ) , denote @xmath639 and @xmath640 and let @xmath641 be the associated string of positive integers .",
    "then for each @xmath33 we have the identities @xmath642 where the above matrices are constructed as @xmath643    let us point out that in the special case @xmath333 we have @xmath644 for some @xmath645 , and the above equations must be interpreted as yielding @xmath646 , @xmath647 .",
    "moreover , as a consequence of the proposition , the matrices determining matching conditions behave well under concatenation ; indeed , if the farey word @xmath25 is the concatenation of two farey words @xmath156 and @xmath157 , then the left - hand side of the matching condition on @xmath28 is the concatenation of the left - hand sides of the matching conditions of @xmath648 and @xmath649 .    before delving into the core of the proofs of proposition [ r : mconcatenazione ] and theorem [ t : anatomy ] let us make some elementary observations and define some more notation .",
    "the action of both @xmath650 can be easily expressed in terms of regular continued fraction expansion , thus the action of @xmath0 on the regular continued fraction expansion of @xmath63 follows some simple rules .",
    "namely , if @xmath651\\in [ \\alpha-1,0)$ ] then one gets the formulas @xmath652 & a_1 >",

    "let us conclude this section by studying the ordering between the iterates of @xmath0 , which will be needed in the last section .",
    "as we shall see , this also follows from the combinatorics of the underlying farey words : in particular , the ordering is the same as the ordering between the cyclic permutations of their farey structure .",

    "we shall now use the combinatorial description of the orbits of @xmath0 we have obtained in the previous section to derive consequences about the entropy of the maps , proving theorem [ t : main ] .    for any fixed @xmath610 ,",
    "the map @xmath0 is a uniformly expanding map of the interval and many general facts about its measurable dynamics are known ( see @xcite ) .",
    "indeed , each @xmath0 has a unique absolutely continuous invariant probability measure ( a.c.i.p . for short ) which we will denote @xmath801 , and the dynamical system @xmath802 is ergodic .",
    "in fact , it is even exact and isomorphic to a bernoulli shift ; moreover , its ergodic properties can also be derived from the properties of the geodesic flow on the modular surface .",
    "let @xmath34 be the metric entropy of @xmath0 with respect to the measure @xmath19 : we shall be interested in studying the properties of the function @xmath35 .",
    "recall that for an expanding map of the interval the entropy can also be given by rohlin s formula @xmath803 moreover , for maps generating continued fraction algorithms such as @xmath0 , the entropy is also related to the growth rate of denominators of convergents to a `` typical '' point .",
    "more precisely , we can define the @xmath8-convergents to @xmath63 to be the sequence @xmath804 where @xmath805 for each @xmath63 , the sequence @xmath806 tends to @xmath63 .",
    "then , for @xmath19-almost every @xmath807",
    "$ ] we have @xmath808    as far as the global regularity of the entropy function is concerned , one can easily adapt the strategy of @xcite to prove that @xmath34 is hlder continuous in @xmath8 :    [ tt : tiozzo ] for any @xmath809 $ ] and any @xmath810 $ ] , the function @xmath35 is hlder continuous of exponent @xmath811 on @xmath812 $ ] .    on the complement of @xmath3",
    "we can exploit the rigidity due to the matching to gain much more regularity .",
    "the key tool will be the following proposition .",
    "[ l : nnformula ] let @xmath813 be nearby points which lie both on the same side with respect to the pseudocenter , with @xmath814 . then the following formulas hold : @xmath815)]h(\\alpha')\\\\ h(\\alpha')=[1-(|w|_0-|w|_1 ) \\mu_{\\alpha'}([\\alpha'-1 , \\alpha-1])]h(\\alpha)\\end{aligned}\\ ] ]    the proof of this proposition follows very closely the proof of the corresponding statement for @xmath8-continued fractions in ( @xcite , theorem 2 ) ; a sketch of the argument is included in the appendix . as a first straightforward consequence of proposition [ l : nnformula ]",
    "we get the local monotonicity of @xmath44 on the complement of @xmath3 .    [",
    "c : localmonotonicity ] the entropy is locally monotone on @xmath36 \\setminus { \\mathcal{e}_{ku}}$ ] .",
    "more precisely :    1 .",
    "the entropy is strictly increasing on @xmath28 if @xmath816 ; 2 .",
    "the entropy is constant on @xmath28 if @xmath817 ; 3 .",
    "the entropy is strictly decreasing on @xmath28 if @xmath818 .",
    "let us point out that corollary [ c : localmonotonicity ] alone is still not enough to deduce the monotonicity on @xmath45 $ ] stated in theorem [ t : main ] .",
    "indeed , @xmath44 is strictly increasing on each open interval @xmath28 for all @xmath500 and the union of all such opens is dense in @xmath819 $ ] , but to conclude that @xmath44 is monotone on @xmath45 $ ] we must exclude that @xmath44 displays pathological behaviour like the `` devil s staircase '' function .",
    "we shall take care of this issue proving that @xmath44 is absolutely continuous .",
    "let us consider the decomposition @xmath820 where @xmath821 } h , \\ \\ \\ \\ h_s(t):=h(t)-h_r(t).\\ ] ] recall the notation @xmath822 means the total variation of the function @xmath491 on the interval @xmath823 .",
    "intuitively , @xmath824 is the `` regular part '' which takes into account the behaviour of @xmath44 on the ( open and dense ) union of the @xmath28 , while @xmath825 is the remaining `` singular part '' , which we will actually prove to be zero .",
    "[ l : loco ] the function @xmath825 is locally constant on @xmath45 \\setminus { \\mathcal{e}_{ku}}$ ] .    if @xmath500 and @xmath826 , @xmath827 , then the monotonicity of @xmath828 implies that @xmath829 } h= h_r(t_2)-h_r(t_1)\\ ] ] which implies @xmath830 , whence the claim .",
    "we shall now need the following lemma in fractal geometry , whose proof we postpone to the appendix .",

    "if @xmath845 $ ] , @xmath846 , then @xmath847 } \\operatorname*{var}_{j_w } h .\\ ] ] by equation , for each @xmath28 we have that @xmath848 ; then we get @xmath849 } \\operatorname*{var}_{j_w } h     \\leq c \\sum_{j_w\\subset[\\beta , \\beta ' ] } |j_w|^{\\eta } \\leq \\\\ & \\leq c c ' \\left(\\sum_{j_w\\subset[\\beta , \\beta ' ] } |j_w|\\right)^{\\eta-\\delta}= c c'|\\beta'-\\beta|^{\\eta-\\delta}\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] for any @xmath850 ; the last line is a direct consequence of lemma [ l : bdim ] and the fact that the box - dimension of @xmath3 is @xmath51 ( proposition [ hdim ] ) .",
    "finally @xmath825 is hlder continuous since it is a difference of two hlder continuous functions ( note the domain has unit length ) .",
    "[ l : extend ] let @xmath851 be a map of a closed real interval which is hlder continuous of exponent @xmath852 .",
    "suppose @xmath853 is a closed , measurable subset of hausdorff dimension less than @xmath811 , and that @xmath491 is locally constant on the complement on @xmath854 .",
    "then @xmath491 is constant on all @xmath823 .",
    "if @xmath491 is hlder continuous of exponent @xmath811 , it is easy to check using the definition of hausdorff dimension that for any measurable subset @xmath854 of the interval one has the estimate @xmath855 now , if @xmath491 is locally constant on @xmath856 , then the image of any connected component of the complement of @xmath854 is a point , hence we have @xmath857 now , if @xmath491 is not constant , then by continuity the image @xmath858 is a non - degenerate interval , hence it has dimension @xmath49 .",
    "thus one has by using equation @xmath859 which is a contradiction .",
    "* proof of theorem [ t : main ] . *",
    "the second statement follows from corollary [ c : localmonotonicity]-(2 ) ; moreover , by virtue of the symmetry of @xmath44 , the third statement is a consequence of the first one , so we just need to prove that the function @xmath44 is strictly increasing on @xmath819 $ ] .    since the function @xmath44 is strictly increasing on each @xmath28 which intersects @xmath819 $ ] ( corollary [ c : localmonotonicity]-(1 ) ) and the union of the @xmath28 is dense , then the function @xmath824 is strictly increasing on @xmath819 $ ] .",
    "the claim then follows if we prove that the function @xmath825 is identically zero , so @xmath860 .",
    "now , by lemma [ l : loco ] @xmath825 is locally constant on the complement of @xmath3 , it is @xmath811-hlder continuous for any positive @xmath861 by lemma [ l : hsholder ] , so since @xmath862 the function @xmath825 is globally constant by lemma [ l : extend ] .",
    "finally , in this section we shall analyze the regularity properties of the entropy function @xmath34 , proving theorem [ t : more ] . in order to do so",
    ", we need some results from the theory of @xmath68-continued fractions due to s. katok and i. ugarcovici . therefore we will outline here some of the results contained in @xcite ; meanwhile , we shall also explain to the reader how our constructions relate to the work of katok and ugarcovici , and translate between the different notations .",
    "the starting point are the `` slow '' maps @xmath863 defined as @xmath864 where the parameters @xmath68 range in the closed region @xmath865 which is plotted in figure [ fig : abpars ] .    -continued fractions .",
    "we only consider the critical line case @xmath866 . ]",
    "an essential role in the theory is played by a condition called _ cycle property _ , which we recall briefly .",
    "if @xmath491 is a real map and @xmath63 is a point , we call _ upper orbit _ ( resp . _ lower orbit _ ) of @xmath63 the countable set of elements @xmath867 ( resp .",
    "@xmath868 ) , with @xmath869 .",
    "we say that the map @xmath20 satisfies the cycle property at the discontinuity points @xmath870 if the upper and lower orbit of @xmath94 eventually collide , and the same is true for @xmath337 . as a matter of fact for most parameters",
    "the cycle property is _ strong _ , meaning that it is the consequence of an identity in @xmath599 , which is stable on an open set . to build a geometrical realization of the natural extension",
    "one defines the family of maps of the plane @xmath871 katok and ugarcovici prove that each @xmath77 has an attractor @xmath78 such that @xmath77 restricted to @xmath79 is invertible and it is a geometric realization of the natural extension of @xmath20 .",
    "in fact , for most values of @xmath2 the attractor @xmath79 has a simple structure :    [ t : ku1 ] there exists an uncountable set @xmath872 of one - dimensional lebesgue measure zero that lies on the diagonal boundary @xmath873 of @xmath70 such that :    1 .   for all @xmath874 the map @xmath77",
    "has an attractor @xmath79 ( which is disjoint from the diagonal @xmath875 ) on which @xmath77 is essentially bijective ; 2 .",
    "the set @xmath79 consists of two ( or one , in the `` degenerate '' case @xmath876 ) connected components each having _ finite rectangular structure _ ,",
    "i.e. bounded by non - decreasing step functions with a finite number of steps ; 3 .",
    "almost every point @xmath877 off the diagonal @xmath875 is mapped to @xmath79 after finitely many iterations of @xmath77 .",
    "the above result shows that exceptions to the finiteness condition dwell on the _ critical line _ @xmath873 .",
    "for this reason , we only consider these cases . with a slight abuse of notation we shall always write @xmath878 rather than @xmath879 .",
    "note that if @xmath873 , the map @xmath74 is precisely the first return map of @xmath72 on the interval @xmath73 .",
    "note also that in the symmetric case @xmath880 ( with @xmath881 $ ] ) the system determined by the first return on @xmath882 $ ] is equivalent to a twofold cover of the @xmath8-continued fraction transformation @xmath883 .    let us note that along the critical line @xmath873 the cycle property is a bit easier to state .",
    "indeed , in this case the upper orbit of @xmath94 coincides with the orbit of @xmath94 , while the lower orbit of @xmath94 coincides with the orbit of @xmath337 ; on the other hand the upper orbit of @xmath337 coincides with the orbit of @xmath94 , while the lower orbit of @xmath337 is just the orbit of @xmath337 .",
    "thus , in this case the _ cycle property _ for @xmath72 is essentially equivalent to the condition for the fast map @xmath74 .",
    "indeed , the set @xmath3 that we explicitely described coincides , up to a countable set of points equals @xmath884 . ] , with the projection on the @xmath63-axis of the set @xmath885 mentioned in theorem [ t : ku1 ] .",
    "now , for @xmath33 the map @xmath0 satisfies the algebraic matching condition , hence @xmath886 satisfies the _ strong cycle property _ ( see @xcite ) and by theorem [ t : ku1 ] the extension @xmath887 has an attractor @xmath888 with _",
    "finite rectangular structure_. we may also consider the `` first return map '' map @xmath889 defined as @xmath890 note that the map @xmath0 is a factor of @xmath891 . obviously the set @xmath892 $ ] is an attractor for @xmath891 . in order to compactify the attractor it is convenient to make the change of coordinates @xmath893 ; then , the natural extension map becomes @xmath894 which is just the map @xmath891 in the new coordinates : @xmath895 .",
    "the map @xmath896 will have the attractor @xmath897)$ ] , which is bounded and has finite rectangular structure .     and its image @xmath898 . ]      in ( @xcite ,",
    "section 5 ) the authors prove that the attractor @xmath888 has finite rectangular structure providing an explicit recipe to build it ; one can easily translate this recipe in order to obtain the following analogue description for @xmath898 for @xmath33 .",
    "let us fix @xmath153 a farey word , with @xmath899 , and pick @xmath900 .",
    "then the attractor @xmath898 is the union of finitely many rectangles with sides parallel to the coordinate axes , and the sides of these rectangles are determined by the dynamics of @xmath0 prior to the matching , as we now describe .     for @xmath901 :",
    "the numbers and arrows indicate the dynamics of the horizontal boundary segments .",
    "note that the vertical ordering of the horizontal segments follows the ordering of the cyclic translates of the corresponding farey word ( in this case , @xmath300 ) . ]    the horizontal segments which delimit @xmath898 are of precisely two types , corresponding to the orbits of @xmath8 and @xmath29 , respectively ; in particular , the set of levels ( ordinates ) of the horizontal segments on the `` lower - right '' part of @xmath898 is precisely the set @xmath902 of iterates of @xmath29 up to the matching , while the set of levels of the horizontal segments on the `` upper - right '' side is the set @xmath903 the coordinates of the vertical sides of the boundary of @xmath898 ( hence the abscissae of its corners ) can instead be found in a slightly indirect way , also described in @xcite : in order to explain it , let @xmath904 and @xmath905 denote , respectively , the upper - right and lower - left corners of the attractor @xmath898 .    1 .   the highest horizontal segment which delimits @xmath898 has endpoints @xmath906 and @xmath904 , while the lowest one is the segment of endpoints @xmath905 and @xmath907 ; 2 .",
    "the horizontal segments which form the upper boundary of @xmath898 are images under @xmath896 of the segment of endpoints @xmath906 and @xmath904 , and similarly the horizontal segments which bound @xmath898 from below are images under @xmath896 of the segment of endpoints @xmath905 and @xmath907 ; 3 .",
    "the values of @xmath63 and @xmath908 are determined by asking that the projection of the horizontal segments bounding @xmath898 from above ( resp .",
    "below ) project to adjacent segments ; it turns out that it is enough to check this condition on a couple of adiacent levels on the top and on the bottom , and this boils down to an algebraic relation which only depends on the symbolic orbit of @xmath8 and @xmath29 . in particular",
    ", it is enough to ask that the right endpoint of the lowest level matches with the left endpoint of the level immediately above it .",
    "similarly , one needs to ask that the left endpoint of the highest level matches with the right endpoint of the level immediately below it .",
    "that is , if we let @xmath909 be the projection on the @xmath63-coordinate and @xmath910 be chosen such that @xmath911    then , as a consequence of this discussion , the values @xmath912 are determined by the following system : @xmath913 once @xmath63 and @xmath908 are known , then the other vertical levels are obtained by iterating @xmath896 on @xmath63 and @xmath908 ; note that , as a consequence , the absicssae of the vertical segments depend _ only on the qumterval @xmath28 _ and do not depend on the particular @xmath8 inside @xmath28 .",
    "we shall now combine this recipe with the results of section [ s : matching ] and find the following explicit formulas for @xmath63 and @xmath908 .",
    "[ p : maledetta ] let @xmath914 $ ] be a qumterval  and @xmath915 ; then @xmath916 $ ] and @xmath917 $ ] .    in general",

    "let us remark that the study of the entropy @xmath1001 in the case of the family @xmath50 of @xmath8-continued fractions of nakada is indeed much more complicated than the case examined in this paper .",
    "actually many statements that we proved before should hold also for the family @xmath50 , but proofs are missing .",
    "the structure of the matching set for @xmath8-continued fractions is quite well understood ( @xcite , @xcite ) , but in this case matching intervals with different monotonic behaviours are mixed up in a complicated way ( @xcite ) , so even the fact that the entropy @xmath1001 attains its maximum value at @xmath340 is still conjectural .     of nakada s @xmath8-continued fractions ( in blue ) , versus the entropy @xmath44 of continued fractions with @xmath1 branches ( in pink ) . ]",
    "another feature which is still unproved is the smoothness of entropy on matching intervals .",
    "this is due to the fact that the natural extension has no finite rectangular structure when @xmath8 ranges in a matching interval ( see @xcite ) .",
    "we conjecture that , as in the case we examined in this paper , on a matching interval densities are piecewise continuous , with discontinuity points located on the forward images of the endpoints ( before matching occurs ) , while the branches of these densities are fractional transformation which move smoothly with the parameter ( see also @xcite , conj .",
    "we shall now give the proofs of a few technical lemmas we postponed in the main body of the article .",

    "since the proof follows closely the same strategy as in @xcite we give here just a sketch of the main steps .",

    "_ local connectivity of julia sets and bifurcation loci : three theorems of j .- c .",
    ", in _ topological methods in modern mathematics ( stony brook , ny , 1991 ) _ , 467511 , publish or perish , houston , tx , 1993 ."
  ],
  "abstract_text": [
    "<S> we study the dynamics of a family @xmath0 of discontinuous interval maps whose ( infinitely many ) branches are mbius transformations in @xmath1 , and which arise as the critical - line case of the family of @xmath2__-continued fractions__.    we provide an explicit construction of the bifurcation locus @xmath3 for this family , showing it is parametrized by farey words and it has hausdorff dimension zero . as a consequence , </S>",
    "<S> we prove that the metric entropy of @xmath0 is analytic outside the bifurcation set but not differentiable at points of @xmath3 , and that the entropy is monotone as a function of the parameter .    </S>",
    "<S> finally , we prove that the bifurcation set is combinatorially isomorphic to the main cardioid in the mandelbrot set , providing one more entry to the dictionary developed by the authors between continued fractions and complex dynamics . </S>"
  ]
}
